3. Digital and Technology -Driven Economies  
These models emerge from technological innovation and digitalization:  
• Digital Economy : Driven by digital technologies and online commerce  
• Platform Economy : Based on digital platforms connecting users and providers  
• Gig Economy : Characterized by short -term, flexible work via digital platforms  
• Attention Economy : Monetizing human attention through media and advertising  
• Crypto Economy : Using cryptocurrencies and blockchain for transactions  
• Autonomous Economy : Driven by automation and self -regulating systems  
• Network Economy : Based on interconnectedness through technology  
• Space Economy : Tied to space exploration and extraterrestrial resources  
4. Social Value and Community -Oriented Economies  
These prioritize social connections, equity, and community well -being:  
• Social Economy : Focused on social goals through cooperatives and nonprofits  
• Solidarity Economy : Based on mutual support and collective ownership  
• Feminist Economy : Prioritizing gender equity and valuing unpaid care work  
• Local Economy : Focused on regional production for community resilience  
• Collaborative Economy : Emphasizing cooperation and shared resources  
• Meaning Economy : Deriving value from purpose and societal significance  
• Token Economy : Using tokens or rewards to incentivize specific behaviors  
5. Experience and Well -being Economies  
These focus on human experiences, services, and quality of life:  
• Experience Economy : Centred  on selling memorable experiences  
• Wellness Economy : Focused on health, fitness, and well -being products  
• Silver Economy : Catering to the needs of aging populations  
• Creative Economy : Driven by creativity, culture, and intellectual property  
• Knowledge Economy : Value derived from intellectual capital and innovation  
6. Resource -Sharing and Access -Based Economies  
These emphasize access over ownership and resource optimization:  
• Sharing Economy : Based on sharing underutilized assets  
• Peer -to-Peer (P2P) Economy : Direct transactions between individuals  
• Subscription Economy : Recurring fees for ongoing access to goods/services  
• Resilience Economy : Designed to withstand economic and environmental shocks  
• Global Economy : Interconnected system of international trade and investment  
 
Economic Sectors  
1. Primary Sector  
Definition : Involves the extraction and harvesting of natural resources directly from the 
Earth.  
Key Characteristics : 
• Directly dependent on natural resources  
• Often labo ur-intensive, especially in developing economies  
• Forms the foundation of all other economic activities  
Economic Activities : 
• Agriculture: Cultivation of crops (wheat, rice, corn)  
• Livestock Farming: Raising animals for meat, dairy, and other products  
• Fishing: Harvesting fish and other seafood  
• Forestry: Logging and management of forests for timber  
• Mining: Extraction of minerals, metals, and fossil fuels  
• Quarrying: Extraction of stone, sand, and gravel  
• Hunting and Gathering: Traditional methods of obtaining food and resources  
• Water Collection: Harvesting and distribution of freshwater resources  
2. Secondary Sector  
Definition : Involves the processing and manufacturing of raw materials into finished or 
semi -finished products.  
Key Characteristics : 
• Adds value to raw materials through industrial processes  
• Includes both small -scale (artisanal) and large -scale (industrial) production  
• Often capital -intensive and technology -driven  
Economic Activities : 
• Manufacturing: Production of goods (textiles, electronics, automobiles)  
• Construction: Building infrastructure (roads, bridges, buildings)  
• Processing: Transforming raw materials (refining oil, milling flour)  
• Energy Production: Generating electricity

3. Market Economy (Capitalist Economy): An economy driven by supply and demand, 
where individuals and businesses make decisions about production and consumption 
with minimal government intervention (e.g., United States).  
4. Mixed Economy: An economy combining elements of market, command, and traditional 
systems, balancing private enterprise with government regulation (e.g., most modern 
nations like Canada).  
5. Gig Economy: An economy characterized by short -term, flexible, or freelance work, 
often facilitated by digital platforms (e.g., Uber, Fiverr).  
6. Attention Economy: An economy where human attention is a scarce commodity, 
monetized through advertising and media (e.g., social media platforms).  
7. Circular Economy: An economy focused on reducing waste by reusing, recycling, and 
regenerating resources in a closed -loop system (e.g., upcycling initiatives).  
8. Sharing Economy: An economy based on sharing or renting underutilized assets, often 
peer-to-peer, enabled by technology (e.g., Airbnb, car -sharing).  
9. Digital Economy: An economy driven by digital technologies, including online 
commerce, data, and connectivity (e.g., e -commerce like Amazon).  
10. Green Economy: An economy prioritizing environmental sustainability through 
renewable energy, conservation, and eco -friendly practices (e.g., solar power 
industries).  
11. Knowledge Economy: An economy where value is derived from intellectual capital, 
innovation, and information rather than physical goods (e.g., tech research hubs).  
12. Experience Economy: An economy centred on selling memorable experiences rather 
than just products or services (e.g., theme parks, immersive events).  
13. Platform Economy: An economy based on digital platforms that connect users, 
producers, and consumers (e.g., Google, Facebook).  
14. Social Economy: An economy focused on social goals, often through cooperatives, 
nonprofits, and community -driven initiatives (e.g., fair trade organizations).  
15. Blue Economy: An economy leveraging sustainable use of ocean and water resources 
(e.g., aquaculture, maritime shipping).  
16. Silver Economy: An economy catering to the needs of aging populations, focusing on 
healthcare, leisure, and retirement services (e.g., elder care products).  
17. Creative Economy: An economy driven by creativity, culture, and intellectual property 
(e.g., arts, media, design).  
18. Informal Economy: An economy of unregulated, often cash -based activities outside 
formal systems (e.g., street vending).  
19. Barter Economy: An economy where goods and services are exchanged directly without 
money (e.g., trading crops for tools).  
20. Gift Economy: An economy based on giving without expecting immediate return, often 
rooted in social bonds (e.g., community support systems).  
21. Doughnut Economy: An economy balancing human needs within planetary boundaries, 
aiming for sustainability and equity (e.g., Amsterdam’s adoption model).  
22. Steady-State Economy: An economy maintaining stable resource use and population, 
avoiding growth for sustainability (e.g., theoretical ecological model).  
23. Local Economy: An economy focused on regional production and consumption to 
strengthen community resilience (e.g., farmers' markets).  
24. Global Economy: An interconnected economy of international trade, investment, and 
production (e.g., WTO -governed systems).  
25. Network Economy: An economy driven by interconnectedness and relationships, often 
through technology (e.g., internet -based businesses).  
26. Subscription Economy: An economy where consumers pay recurring fees for ongoing 
access to goods or services (e.g., Netflix, software subscriptions).  
27. Token Economy: An economy using tokens or rewards to incentivize behavior, often in 
controlled settings (e.g., behavioral therapy systems).

29. Regenerative Economy: An economy restoring ecosystems and communities through 
sustainable practices (e.g., regenerative agriculture).  
30. Feminist Economy: An economy prioritizing gender equity, valuing unpaid care work, 
and challenging patriarchal structures (e.g., policies for equal pay).  
31. Resilience Economy: An economy designed to withstand shocks like climate change or 
economic crises (e.g., disaster -prepared communities).  
32. Collaborative Economy: An economy emphasizing cooperation and shared resources, 
overlapping with sharing models (e.g., co -working spaces).  
33. Autonomous Economy: An economy driven by automation and self -regulating systems, 
reducing human labor (e.g., AI -managed supply chains).  
34. Solidarity Economy: An economy based on mutual support, social justice, and 
collective ownership (e.g., worker cooperatives).  
35. Crypto Economy: An economy using cryptocurrencies and blockchain for decentralized 
transactions (e.g., Bitcoin ecosystem).  
36. Wellness Economy: An economy focused on health, fitness, and well -being products 
and services (e.g., yoga studios, organic foods).  
37. Space Economy: An economy tied to space exploration, satellites, and extraterrestrial 
resource use (e.g., SpaceX ventures).  
38. Hydrogen Economy: An economy centered on hydrogen as a clean energy source (e.g., 
hydrogen fuel cells).  
39. Post-Growth Economy: An economy rejecting perpetual growth, focusing on well -being 
and sustainability (e.g., degrowth movements).  
40. Meaning Economy: An economy where value is derived from purpose, fulfilment , and 
personal or societal significance, prioritizing meaningful work and experiences over 
material gain (e.g., social impact careers, purpose -driven businesses like B Corps).  
Clustering these Economies  
1. Foundational Economic Systems  
These represent the fundamental organizing principles for economies:  
• Traditional Economy : Based on customs, traditions, and historical practices  
• Command Economy : Government -controlled production and distribution  
• Market Economy : Driven by supply and demand with minimal government 
intervention  
• Mixed Economy : Combination of market, command, and traditional elements  
• Informal Economy : Unregulated activities outside formal systems  
• Barter Economy : Direct exchange of goods without money  
• Gift Economy : Giving without expectation of immediate return  
2. Sustainability -Focused Economies  
These models prioritize environmental conservation and sustainable resource use:  
• Circular Economy : Reducing waste through reusing and recycling resources  
• Green Economy : Prioritizing environmental sustainability and eco -friendly practices  
• Blue Economy : Sustainable use of ocean and water resources  
• Doughnut Economy : Balancing human needs within planetary boundaries  
• Steady -State Economy : Maintaining stable resource use and population  
• Regenerative Economy : Restoring ecosystems through sustainable practices  
• Post-Growth Economy : Rejecting perpetual growth for sustainability  
• Hydrogen Economy : Centered on hydrogen as a clean energy source

Planning The Refracted Economies 
Framework  
Colour-Coded Economies  
What is the rationale for these colours  
1. Orange Economy: Creative, cultural, and leisure activities (arts, media, sports, tourism, 
fashion).  
• Purpose: To create, express, and facilitate cultural experiences that enrich 
society's emotional, artistic, and recreational dimensions.  
2. Green Economy: Environmental sustainability ( Energy, renewable energy, conservation, 
recycling).  
• Purpose: To protect, restore, and sustain natural environments while developing 
systems that enable human prosperity without environmental degradation.  
3. Blue Economy: Water -resource -based activities (fishing, maritime transport, coastal 
tourism).  
• Purpose: To responsibly harvest, utilize, and protect oceanic and water 
resources while enabling transportation and experiences connected to aquatic 
environments.  
4. Lavender Economy: Care and helping professions (healthcare, social work, counselling).  
• Purpose: To nurture, heal, and support human well -being through direct care, 
emotional support, and health services across the lifespan.  
5. Yellow Economy: Public/social sector (government, education, NGOs).  
• Purpose: To govern, educate, and advance social welfare through public 
institutions and non -profit organizations serving collective societal needs.  
6. Bronze Economy: Extraction and cultivation (mining, agriculture, forestry).  
• Purpose: To extract raw materials and cultivate natural resources that form the 
foundation of physical goods production and energy generation.  
7. Iron Economy: Manufacturing, distribution, and infrastructure (construction, logistics, 
retail).  
• Purpose: To transform raw materials into finished products and ensure their 
distribution through physical infrastructure and logistical networks.  
8. Gold Economy: Financial services (banking, insurance, fintech).  
• Purpose: To facilitate financial flows, manage risk, and allocate capital to enable 
economic activity and wealth management across all sectors.  
9. Platinum Economy:  Technology and innovation (IT, AI, software development).  
• Purpose: To develop technological solutions and innovations that enhance 
capabilities, efficiency, and possibilities across all other economic domains.

10.2. Digital and Emerging Skills  
 
The green economy is increasingly data -driven, and a new suite of digital skills is 
becoming essential for optimizing processes, improving monitoring, and driving 
innovation.  
● Energy and Environmental Modelling:  Proficiency in specialized software is a 
key differentiator. This includes energy modeling software  like PVSyst for solar 
design 112, 
thermodynamic modeling  for energy efficiency analysis 78, and software for 
conducting  
Life Cycle Assessments (LCAs)  of products and processes.  
● Geographic Information Systems (GIS):  GIS skills are critical across multiple 
sectors for spatial planning and analysis. This includes site selection for 
renewable energy projects, mapping biodiversity hotspots for conservation 
planning, and planning urban green infrastructure.  
● Data Analysis and Remote Sensing:  The ability to analyze large datasets from 
environmental monitoring is becoming crucial. This includes interpreting data 
from remote sensors, drones, and satellite imagery for applications such as 
monitoring deforestation, assessing crop health, and tracking air or water 
pollution.  
● Internet of Things (IoT) and Smart Grids:  In the energy and water sectors, 
skills related to IoT are emerging. This involves using sensor networks for real -
time monitoring and control of resources, such as in smart grid technologies  for 
managing electricity distribution or in smart water metering  for demand -side 
management.9 
 
10.3. Interpersonal and Management Capabilities  
 
Often termed "soft skills," these capabilities are arguably the most critical for 
translating technical solutions into real -world impact. The complexity and multi -
stakeholder nature of the green economy place a high premium on these skills.  
● Project Management:  This is the most consistently demanded management 
capability across all green sectors. From managing the construction of a wind 
farm to implementing a corporate sustainability strategy or overseeing a 
community restoration project, the ability to manage s cope, budgets, and 
timelines is fundamental.44 
● Stakeholder Engagement and Community Liaison:  The success of many green 
projects hinges on effective engagement with a wide range of stakeholders, 
including government officials, private sector partners, and local communities. 
Skills in community liaison , facilitation, and negotiation are particularly 
important for projects that have a direct impact on local land use and livelihoods, 
such as mining, renewable energy, and conservation.33 
● Communication and Technical Report Writing:  The ability to communicate 
complex technical and financial information clearly and persuasively is essential. 
This includes writing detailed technical reports  for EIAs, engineering designs, 
and audit findings, as well as developing compelling content for awareness 
campaigns  and policy briefs.48 
● Cross -Disciplinary Collaboration:  Green economy challenges are inherently 
interdisciplinary. Professionals must be able to work effectively in teams that 
include engineers, scientists, financiers, lawyers, and social scientists. This 
requires an appreciation for different professional perspectives and a 
collaborative mindset.  
● Business Acumen and Financial Literacy:  A growing number of "green" roles,
